Gradual Federated Learning with Simulated Annealing

Luong Trung Nguyen, Junhan Kim, and Byonghyo Shim A part of this paper was presented at the International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing (ICASSP), 2021 [1]. This work was supported by Samsung Research Funding & Incubation Center for Future Technology of Samsung Electronics under Project Number SRFC-IT1901-17. Information System Laboratory
Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Seoul National University
Email: {ltnguyen,junhankim,bshim}@islab.snu.ac.kr
Abstract

Federated averaging (FedAvg) is a popular federated learning (FL) technique that updates the global model by averaging local models and then transmits the updated global model to devices for their local model update. One main limitation of FedAvg is that the average-based global model is not necessarily better than local models in the early stage of the training process so that FedAvg might diverge in realistic scenarios, especially when the data is non-identically distributed across devices and the number of data samples varies significantly from device to device. In this paper, we propose a new FL technique based on simulated annealing. The key idea of the proposed technique, henceforth referred to as simulated annealing-based FL (SAFL), is to allow a device to choose its local model when the global model is immature. Specifically, by exploiting the simulated annealing strategy, we make each device choose its local model with high probability in early iterations when the global model is immature. From extensive numerical experiments using various benchmark datasets, we demonstrate that SAFL outperforms the conventional FedAvg technique in terms of the convergence speed and the classification accuracy.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging distributed learning technique where hundreds or thousands of devices jointly train a common machine learning (ML) model without exchanging their local dataset with the centralized server or other devices [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. A wide range of FL applications include human face recognition, next-word prediction, resource allocation, device tracking, basestation association, cyberattack detection, to name just a few [7, 8, 9, 10]. In the FL-based approach, a learning task is performed in an iterative fashion, mainly following by three steps (see Fig. 1). First, a server sets up a common ML model and then broadcasts the model to the user devices. Second, user devices train the model locally and individually using their own local datasets. Third, the server evaluates the model by aggregating the locally trained parameters sent by the devices.

The central challenge of FL is to improve the learning capability of user devices without sharing their own datasets with other devices. In fact, due to various reasons such as user privacy and limited resources (e.g., computing hardware, battery power, network capacity, bandwidth), data generated in one device cannot be transmitted to the server or other devices. One well-known approach to deal with this issue is federated averaging (FedAvg) [2]. In this technique, instead of transmitting data, each device transmits locally trained parameters (e.g., gradients or updated model parameters) to the server. The server updates the global model by averaging the local parameters and then sends the updated model back to devices for the local model update.

While FedAvg is effective in solving nonconvex problem, it has been shown that FedAvg and its variants might diverge in realistic scenarios where the data is non-identically distributed across devices (e.g., data of different languages in the next-word prediction application) and/or the number of data samples significantly varies from device to device [3, 20]. One important reason for the divergence of FedAvg is that the average-based global model is not necessarily better than locally trained models so that just relying on the global model might degrade the entire learning process [11, 12, 13]. To illustrate this, we consider a simple FL task whose goal is to minimize the cost function given by

J​(𝐰;𝒟)=∑(𝐱i,yi)∈𝒟(yi−𝐱iT​𝐰)2+‖𝐰‖1,𝐽𝐰𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑇𝐰2subscriptnorm𝐰1J(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D})=\sum\limits_{(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})\in\mathcal{D}}(y_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{i}^{T}\mathbf{w})^{2}+\|\mathbf{w}\|_{1}, (1)

where 𝒟={(𝐱i,yi)}i𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖\mathcal{D}=\{(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})\}_{i} is the training dataset and ‖𝐰‖1=|w1|+|w2|subscriptnorm𝐰1subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2\|\mathbf{w}\|_{1}=|w_{1}|+|w_{2}| is the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm of 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}. For simplicity, we consider two devices with the local datasets 𝒟1={([14​ 0]T,−1)}subscript𝒟1superscriptdelimited-[]14 0𝑇1\mathcal{D}_{1}=\{([\frac{1}{4}\ 0]^{T},-1)\} and 𝒟2={([0​32]T,1)}subscript𝒟2superscriptdelimited-[]032𝑇1\mathcal{D}_{2}=\{([0\ \frac{3}{2}]^{T},1)\}. One can easily check that the parameters 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} minimizing the cost function J​(𝐰;𝒟)𝐽𝐰𝒟J(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}) with respect to 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} and 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} are 𝐰(1)=[0 0]Tsuperscript𝐰1superscriptdelimited-[]00𝑇\mathbf{w}^{(1)}=[0\ 0]^{T} and 𝐰(2)=[0​49]Tsuperscript𝐰2superscriptdelimited-[]049𝑇\mathbf{w}^{(2)}=[0\ \frac{4}{9}]^{T}, respectively (see Appendix A). Using 𝐰(1)superscript𝐰1\mathbf{w}^{(1)} and 𝐰(2)superscript𝐰2\mathbf{w}^{(2)}, we obtain the average-based model 𝐰¯¯𝐰\overline{\mathbf{w}} evaluated at the server: 𝐰¯=12​(𝐰(1)+𝐰(2))=[0​29]T¯𝐰12superscript𝐰1superscript𝐰2superscriptdelimited-[]029𝑇\overline{\mathbf{w}}=\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{w}^{(1)}+\mathbf{w}^{(2)})=[0\ \frac{2}{9}]^{T}. Since the optimum weight over 𝒟1∪𝒟2subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{1}\cup\mathcal{D}_{2} is 𝐰∗=[0​49]Tsubscript𝐰∗superscriptdelimited-[]049𝑇\mathbf{w}_{\ast}=[0\ \frac{4}{9}]^{T}, we have

‖𝐰∗−𝐰¯‖2=29>0=‖𝐰∗−𝐰(2)‖2,subscriptnormsubscript𝐰∗¯𝐰2290subscriptnormsubscript𝐰∗superscript𝐰22\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}_{\ast}-\overline{\mathbf{w}}\|_{2}=\frac{2}{9}>0=\|\mathbf{w}_{\ast}-\mathbf{w}^{(2)}\|_{2},

which implies that the average value 𝐰¯¯𝐰\overline{\mathbf{w}} is worse than the locally generated value 𝐰(2)superscript𝐰2\mathbf{w}^{(2)}. In this scenario, clearly, it would be better for the second device to use its own solution 𝐰(2)superscript𝐰2\mathbf{w}^{(2)} instead of the server feedback 𝐰¯¯𝐰\overline{\mathbf{w}}. Simply put, the moral of the story is that collaboration might do more harm than good, especially when things are not ready.

Our intent in this paper is to put forth a simple yet effective FL strategy overcoming the problem we mentioned. Key idea of the proposed approach, referred to as the simulated annealing-based FL (SAFL), is that we encourage each device to stay with its locally trained model instead of relying on the collaborative learning model in the early stage of the learning process. When the collaborative model becomes mature and reliable after the reasonable number of iterations, we use the server-generated model to update the device. This idea can be well explained using the simulated annealing (SA) strategy. In the SA strategy, the solution space is searched by imposing perturbations on the estimates of parameters [14, 15, 16, 17, 18]. In the early stage (a.k.a., heating stage), the SA algorithm decides to move the system to a new (presumably perturbation) state with high probability, even though the new state might not be better than the current state, to avoid the chance of trapping in the local optima. In the later stage (a.k.a., cooling stage), the SA algorithm reduces the exploration of the perturbation space.

Inspired by the SA strategy, the proposed SAFL updates the local model of each user probabilistically. To be specific, SAFL decides whether the device keeps its own locally updated model with some modification (i.e., perturbation update) or uses the global evaluation model provided by the server (i.e., server feedback) (see Fig. 2). In the early iterations where the global model is immature, we give a favor to the locally updated model by setting the local model selection probability high. As the number of iterations increases, we gradually reduce this probability so that the device relies more on the server feedback, which helps to avoid the overfitting to the local dataset.

The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We propose a new FL technique called SAFL (Section II) inspired by the SA technique. From extensive numerical experiments on various datasets including MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR-10, and Google speech commands, we demonstrate that the proposed SAFL technique is effective and in fact outperforms the conventional FedAvg technique by a large margin in terms of accuracy and convergence speed (Section V). Specifically, in the MNIST dataset, SAFL converges two times faster than FedAvg and also achieves more than 50%percent5050\% improvement in the classification accuracy.

  • •

    We analyze the performance of the proposed SAFL technique (Section III). Specifically, we show that under some suitable conditions, the mean squares error (MSE) of SAFL satisfies

    E​[‖𝐰^−𝐰∗‖22]𝐸delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm^𝐰subscript𝐰22\displaystyle E[\|\widehat{\mathbf{w}}-\mathbf{w}_{*}\|_{2}^{2}] ≤ξabsent𝜉\displaystyle\leq\xi

    after 𝒪​(1ξ)𝒪1𝜉\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\xi}) iterations where 𝐰^^𝐰\widehat{\mathbf{w}} is the evaluated model parameters and 𝐰∗subscript𝐰\mathbf{w}_{*} is the optimal model parameters (see Theorem III.1).

  • •

    We extend SAFL to the scenario where the performance of the average-based global model is degraded due to non-i.i.d. data and data imbalance among devices (Section IV). Our key idea is to detect biased local updates by measuring the performance gap between the global and local models. Specifically, if the performance gap is large, then we consider the local update as a biased update and do not upload it to the server. In doing so, we can exclude the biased local update in the update of the global model and prevent the performance degradation of the global model. From the numerical results, we demonstrate that the extended SAFL is effective in handling the non-i.i.d. data and reducing the number of local updates uploaded to the server (see Section V).

II Proposed SAFL Algorithm

We consider a communication system consisting of one central server and n𝑛n user devices. The server generates a global model with parameters 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and then transmits the generated model to s𝑠s selected devices (1≤s≤n)1𝑠𝑛(1\leq s\leq n). Each selected device has its own dataset 𝒟(k)={(𝐱i(k),yi(k))}i=1mksuperscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘𝑖1subscript𝑚𝑘\mathcal{D}^{(k)}=\{(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{(k)},y_{i}^{(k)})\}_{i=1}^{m_{k}} to train the local model, where 𝐱i(k)∈ℝqsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑘superscriptℝ𝑞\mathbf{x}_{i}^{(k)}\in\mathbb{R}^{q} is an input data sample (e.g., image), yi(k)superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘y_{i}^{(k)} is the class label of 𝐱i(k)superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑘\mathbf{x}_{i}^{(k)}, and mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k} is the number of data samples in the k𝑘k-th device. We consider the standard FL setting where devices cannot exchange their own datasets with other devices or the central server. In each iteration, FedAvg updates the model parameters 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} (e.g., weights and biases) by taking the following steps. First, using its own dataset 𝒟(k)superscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}^{(k)}, each user device updates the model parameters locally to minimize the loss function F​(𝐰;𝒟(k))𝐹𝐰superscript𝒟𝑘F(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}^{(k)}).111For example, if the mean squared error (MSE) is employed as a loss function, then F​(𝐰;𝒟)=1|𝒟|​∑(𝐱,y)∈𝒟12​(𝐱T​𝐰−y)2𝐹𝐰𝒟1𝒟subscript𝐱𝑦𝒟12superscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑇𝐰𝑦2F(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D})=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}|}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\mathcal{D}}\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{x}^{T}\mathbf{w}-y)^{2}. For example, the update expression of the model parameters 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)} at the k𝑘k-th device is

𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)} =𝐰t−1(k)−α​∂F​(𝐰;𝒟(k))∂𝐰|𝐰=𝐰t−1(k),absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘evaluated-at𝛼𝐹𝐰superscript𝒟𝑘𝐰𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘\displaystyle=\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)}-\alpha\left.\frac{\partial F(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}^{(k)})}{\partial\mathbf{w}}\right|_{\mathbf{w}=\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)}}, (2)

where α𝛼\alpha is the learning rate and 𝐰t−1(k)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)} is the local model parameters after t−1𝑡1t-1 iterations. Second, the server aggregates the local updates 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)} to evaluate the global model parameters. The update expression of the global evaluation model is

𝐳¯t=∑k=1nηk​𝐳t(k),subscript¯𝐳𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝜂𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\bar{\mathbf{z}}_{t}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\eta_{k}\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}, (3)

where ηksubscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{k} is the coefficient satisfying ∑kηk=1subscript𝑘subscript𝜂𝑘1\sum_{k}\eta_{k}=1.222We consider the generic setting of ηksubscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{k} which is an arbitrary value defined by user. A typical setting of ηksubscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{k} is ηk=mk∑kmksubscript𝜂𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘\eta_{k}=\frac{m_{k}}{\sum_{k}m_{k}} [2]. Note that when s<n𝑠𝑛s<n, we simply set ηk=0subscript𝜂𝑘0\eta_{k}=0 for non-selected devices. Finally, the server transmits the globally updated parameters 𝐳¯tsubscript¯𝐳𝑡\bar{\mathbf{z}}_{t} to the selected devices to update the local models. That is, the local model parameters 𝐰t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘\mathbf{w}_{t}^{(k)} is updated as

𝐰t(k)={𝐳¯tif the device receives ​𝐳¯t𝐳t(k)otherwise.\mathbf{w}_{t}^{(k)}=\left\{\begin{matrix}\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t}&\text{if the device receives }\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t}\\ \mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}&\text{otherwise}\end{matrix}\right.. (4)

One potential drawback of the conventional FedAvg technique is that an entire FL process can be degraded by applying the hard-decision rule in (4). This is because the global evaluation model 𝐳¯tsubscript¯𝐳𝑡\bar{\mathbf{z}}_{t} is not necessarily better than locally updated parameters 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)} in many practical scenarios. For example, in the next word prediction application, a language model is trained to predict which word comes next when the initial text fragment is given. In heterogeneous scenarios, users with different countries might use their own mother languages with different grammar and word combination rules (e.g., a subject-verb-object (SVO) rule is used in English, while a subject-object-verb (SOV) rule is used in Korean). Since the next word prediction task is performed with different language rules, the average-based model might perform much worse than the locally trained language model of a local device.

As another example, one can consider the face and object recognition problem where a classification model is trained to identify the user’s face ID. The local dataset collected from user’s personal images is often non-i.i.d. distributed across devices. Since the global model is aggregated by averaging the locally trained models, it may overfit to the local data. In this case, if the device uses the average-based model exclusively, the device might also suffer the overfiting problem, even when the good training dataset is available. Indeed, it has been shown that FedAvg can diverge in such non-i.i.d. scenario [3, 20].

Inspired by this observation, we first define a weighted sum model that incorporates 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)} and 𝐳¯tsubscript¯𝐳𝑡\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t}. The corresponding local update model is expressed as

𝐰t(k)={ϵ​𝐳¯t+(1−ϵ)​𝐳t(k)if the device receives ​𝐳¯t𝐳t(k)otherwise.\mathbf{w}_{t}^{(k)}=\left\{\begin{matrix}\epsilon\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t}+(1-\epsilon)\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}&\text{if the device receives }\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t}\\ \mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}&\text{otherwise}\end{matrix}\right.. (5)

where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the regularization parameter used to control the contribution of the global evaluation model in (5). For example, by setting ϵ=1italic-ϵ1\epsilon=1, the update expression (5) is returned to the conventional FL case. Whereas, by setting ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0, the device ignores the server feedback 𝐳¯tsubscript¯𝐳𝑡\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t} and continues to use the locally trained model 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}.

For the model selection, we consider a strategy inspired by the SA algorithm. In the proposed SAFL, we define the normal state ℛtsubscriptℛ𝑡\mathcal{R}_{t} and the perturbation state 𝒫tsubscript𝒫𝑡\mathcal{P}_{t} as 𝐳¯tsubscript¯𝐳𝑡\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t} and ϵ​𝐳¯t+(1−ϵ)​𝐳t(k)italic-ϵsubscript¯𝐳𝑡1italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\epsilon\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t}+(1-\epsilon)\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}, respectively (see Fig. 3). 𝒫tsubscript𝒫𝑡\mathcal{P}_{t} is accepted with probability p=exp⁡(−tL)𝑝𝑡𝐿p=\exp(-\frac{t}{L}) where L𝐿L is a positive constant (a.k.a., the maximum temperature of SA [15]), while ℛtsubscriptℛ𝑡\mathcal{R}_{t} is with probability 1−p1𝑝1-p. To be specific, let 𝐮t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑡𝑘\mathbf{u}_{t}^{(k)} be the random vector whose j𝑗j-th element ujsubscript𝑢𝑗u_{j} satisfies

ujsubscript𝑢𝑗\displaystyle u_{j} ={ϵwith probability ​p=exp⁡(−tL),1with probability ​1−p,absentcasesitalic-ϵwith probability 𝑝𝑡𝐿1with probability 1𝑝\displaystyle=\begin{cases}\epsilon&\text{with probability }p=\exp\left(-\frac{t}{L}\right),\\ 1&\text{with probability }1-p,\end{cases} (6)

then the local update expression (5) can be reformulated as (see Fig. 3)

𝐰t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{t}^{(k)} ={𝐮t(k)⊙𝐳¯t+(𝟏−𝐮t(k))⊙𝐳t(k)if receives ​𝐳¯t𝐳t(k)otherwise.\displaystyle=\left\{\begin{matrix}\mathbf{u}_{t}^{(k)}\odot\bar{\mathbf{z}}_{t}+(\mathbf{1}-\mathbf{u}_{t}^{(k)})\odot\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}&\text{if receives }\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t}\\ \mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}&\text{otherwise}\end{matrix}\right.. (7)

Note that the model selection probability p𝑝p decays exponentially with the number of iteration. In early iterations (i.e., p𝑝p is close to one), each device relies on its locally trained model and thus the local model would be trained mainly by the local dataset. In later iterations (i.e., p𝑝p is close to zero), the device uses the global evaluation model which is presumably more robust to the overfitting problem than the locally trained model.

We note that the server update procedure of SAFL is essentially the same as the conventional FedAvg so that various fusion models can be easily integrated to SAFL [33, 34, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41]. For example, if we integrate the inverse distance aggregation (IDA) fusion model [34] and SAFL, the coefficient ηksubscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{k} is expressed as [37]

ηk=‖𝐳¯t−𝐳t(k)‖2−1∑k=1n‖𝐳¯t−𝐳t(k)‖2−1.subscript𝜂𝑘superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript¯𝐳𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘21superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript¯𝐳𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘21\displaystyle\eta_{k}=\frac{\|\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t}-\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}\|_{2}^{-1}}{\sum\limits_{k=1}^{n}\|\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t}-\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}\|_{2}^{-1}}. (8)

In Algorithm I, we summarize the proposed SAFL algorithm.

III Convergence Analysis of SAFL

In this section, we analyze the convergence behavior of the proposed SAFL. For simplicity, we consider the scenario where each participating device updates its local model using the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) [19]. Let δtsubscript𝛿𝑡\delta_{t} be a user-predefined value satisfying

δtsubscript𝛿𝑡\displaystyle\delta_{t} ={1if the k-th device receives the server feedback ​𝐳¯t,0else,absentcases1if the k-th device receives the server feedback subscript¯𝐳𝑡0else\displaystyle=\begin{cases}1&\text{if the $k$-th device receives the server feedback }\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t},\\ 0&\text{else},\end{cases} (9)

Then, the update expressions (2) and (7) can be reformulated as

𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)} =\displaystyle= 𝐰t−1(k)−α​∇Fk​(𝐰t−1(k);At(ik)),superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘𝛼∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑖𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)}-\alpha\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)};A_{t}^{(i_{k})}), (10)

where the input data At(ik)=(𝐱ik,yik)∈𝒟(k)superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝐱subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝑦subscript𝑖𝑘superscript𝒟𝑘A_{t}^{(i_{k})}=(\mathbf{x}_{i_{k}},y_{i_{k}})\in\mathcal{D}^{(k)} is sampled identically and independently at each iteration. Here, we put no assumption on the data distribution so that our analysis results can be applied for both i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. scenarios. Also note that Fk​(𝐰t−1(k);At(ik))subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑖𝑘F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)};A_{t}^{(i_{k})}) is the cost function with respect to the data sample At(ik)superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑖𝑘A_{t}^{(i_{k})} and Fk​(𝐰t−1(k))subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)}) is the empirical risk function defined as

Before proceeding, we summarize the assumptions used in our analysis:

  • A1

    Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) is non-negative: Fk​(𝐰)≥0subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰0F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\geq 0 and Fk​(𝐰∗)=0subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰∗0F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})=0

  • A2

    Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) is a smooth convex function: λ​𝐈⪰∇2Fk​(𝐰)⪰μ​𝐈succeeds-or-equals𝜆𝐈superscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰succeeds-or-equals𝜇𝐈\lambda\mathbf{I}\succeq\nabla^{2}F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\succeq\mu\mathbf{I} for λ≥μ≥0𝜆𝜇0\lambda\geq\mu\geq 0.

  • A3

    The stochastic gradient ∇Fk​(𝐰t(k);At(ik))∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑖𝑘\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{(k)};A_{t}^{(i_{k})}) has a bounded variance:

    t​r​(V​a​r​(∇Fk​(𝐰t−1(k))−∇Fk​(𝐰t−1(k);At(ik))|𝐰t−1(k)))𝑡𝑟𝑉𝑎𝑟∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘conditional∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘\displaystyle tr(Var(\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)})-\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)};A_{t}^{(i_{k})})|\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)})) ≤σk2.absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\displaystyle\leq\sigma_{k}^{2}. (13)

It is worth mentioning that these assumptions are used in various machine learning problems, such as linear regression, Tikhonov regularization, logistic regression, and support vector machine (SVM) [10, 11, 12].

Without loss of generality, we focus on the minimization problem333The maximization problem can be converted into a minimization problem with the same solution by multiplying the objective function by −11-1. of the empirical risk. Hence, A1 ensures that the objective function is to be minimized to zero. When the objective function has a nonzero lower bound, say, Fk​(𝐰)≥F0subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰subscript𝐹0F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\geq F_{0} for some constant F0subscript𝐹0F_{0}, we simply define a new objective function F~k​(𝐰)=Fk​(𝐰)−F0subscript~𝐹𝑘𝐰subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰subscript𝐹0\widetilde{F}_{k}(\mathbf{w})=F_{k}(\mathbf{w})-F_{0} and easily extend the analysis results to F~k​(𝐰)subscript~𝐹𝑘𝐰\widetilde{F}_{k}(\mathbf{w}). Assumption A2 is popularly used to guarantee a linear convergence rate of many gradient descent-based machine learning techniques [19]. Equivalently, A2 can be expressed as [19]

  • A2a

    ∇Fk​(𝐰)∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) is λ𝜆\lambda-Lipschitz continuous:

    ‖∇Fk​(𝐰2)−∇Fk​(𝐰1)‖2≤λ​‖𝐰2−𝐰1‖2,∀𝐰1,𝐰2.subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰2∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰12𝜆subscriptnormsubscript𝐰2subscript𝐰12for-allsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰2\displaystyle\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{2})-\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{1})\|_{2}\leq\lambda\|\mathbf{w}_{2}-\mathbf{w}_{1}\|_{2},\forall\mathbf{w}_{1},\mathbf{w}_{2}. (14)
  • A2b

    Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) is a μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex function:

    Fk​(𝐰2)subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰2\displaystyle F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{2}) ≥Fk​(𝐰1)+∇Fk​(𝐰1)T​(𝐰2−𝐰1)absentsubscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰1∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰1𝑇subscript𝐰2subscript𝐰1\displaystyle\geq F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{1})+\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{1})^{T}(\mathbf{w}_{2}-\mathbf{w}_{1})
    +μ2​‖𝐰2−𝐰1‖22,∀𝐰1,𝐰2𝜇2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐰2subscript𝐰122for-allsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰2\displaystyle\qquad+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\mathbf{w}_{2}-\mathbf{w}_{1}\|_{2}^{2},\forall\mathbf{w}_{1},\mathbf{w}_{2} (15)

    for λ≥μ≥0𝜆𝜇0\lambda\geq\mu\geq 0.

Intuitively, A2 ensures that there exists a quadratic lower bounds on the growth of the objective function. In our analysis, we use A2, together with Taylor’s expansion, to build a universal upper bound on the MSE of the local updates 𝐰t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘\mathbf{w}_{t}^{(k)}. Assumption A3 is referred to as bounded variance condition in the literature [19], which is widely used in the SGD convergence analysis [20, 21, 22].

In our main theorem, under A1, A2, and A3, we show that the proposed SAFL converges linearly444A sequence {ut}t=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑡𝑡1\{u_{t}\}_{t=1}^{\infty} is said to converge linearly to u∗subscript𝑢∗u_{\ast} if there exists a number λ∈(0,1)𝜆01\lambda\in(0,1) such that limt→∞|ut+1−u∗||ut−u∗|=λsubscript→𝑡subscript𝑢𝑡1subscript𝑢∗subscript𝑢𝑡subscript𝑢∗𝜆\lim\limits_{t\rightarrow\infty}\frac{|u_{t+1}-u_{\ast}|}{|u_{t}-u_{\ast}|}=\lambda. Also, if λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1, then the sequence is said to converge sublinearly to u∗subscript𝑢∗u_{\ast}. to an accurate solution.

Theorem III.1.

Under A1, A2, and A3, the MSE error bound of SAFL satisfies

E​[‖𝐰^t−𝐰∗‖22]𝐸delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript^𝐰𝑡subscript𝐰∗22\displaystyle E[\|\widehat{\mathbf{w}}_{t}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\|_{2}^{2}] ≤(1−α​μ)2​t​ζ+αμ​∑k=1nηk2​σk2​1−(1−α​μ)2​q1−e−c​(1−α​μ)2​q,absentsuperscript1𝛼𝜇2𝑡𝜁𝛼𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜂2𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘21superscript1𝛼𝜇2𝑞1superscript𝑒𝑐superscript1𝛼𝜇2𝑞\displaystyle\leq(1-\alpha\mu)^{2t}\zeta+\frac{\alpha}{\mu}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{n}\eta^{2}_{k}\sigma_{k}^{2}\frac{1-(1-\alpha\mu)^{2q}}{1-e^{-c}(1-\alpha\mu)^{2q}}, (16)

Remark III.2.

The right-hand side of (16) consists of two terms: 1) the first term (1−α​μ)2​t​ζsuperscript1𝛼𝜇2𝑡𝜁(1-\alpha\mu)^{2t}\zeta converges linearly to zero with the iteration t𝑡t and 2) the second term is a function of the learning rate α𝛼\alpha and can be reduced with a small α𝛼\alpha. In fact, when α=𝒪​(1t)𝛼𝒪1𝑡\alpha=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{t}), we can further show that SAFL converges sublinearly to the optimal solution.

One can see that the MSE of the proposed SAFL scales in the order of 𝒪​(1t)𝒪1𝑡\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{t}). This MSE bound matches to the latest results of federated optimization bound [20, 21, 22].

Remark III.4.

Remark III.5.

While we use the convexity assumption A2 to facilitate our analysis, our main result can be readily extended to the case where Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) is not necessarily a strong convex function. For example, we consider the non-negative function Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) satisfying

  • A4

    Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) is μ𝜇\mu-strongly quasi-convex:

    <∇Fk(𝐰),𝐰−𝐰∗>\displaystyle<\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}),\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}> ≥\displaystyle\geq μ2​‖𝐰−𝐰∗‖22.𝜇2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝐰subscript𝐰∗22\displaystyle\frac{\mu}{2}\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\|^{2}_{2}. (18)
  • A5

    The stochastic gradient ∇Fk​(𝐰t(k);At(ik))∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑖𝑘\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{(k)};A_{t}^{(i_{k})}) has a bounded variance:

    E​[‖∇Fk​(𝐰t−1(k);At(ik))‖22]𝐸delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑖𝑘22\displaystyle E[\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{(k)};A_{t}^{(i_{k})})\|_{2}^{2}] ≤\displaystyle\leq σk2.superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\displaystyle\sigma_{k}^{2}. Note that A4 is weaker than A2 since if A2 holds true, then we have

<∇Fk(𝐰),𝐰−𝐰∗>\displaystyle<\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}),\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}> =(a)𝑎\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{=} Fk​(𝐰)−Fk​(𝐰∗)+12​(𝐰−𝐰∗)T​∇2Fk​(𝝃)​(𝐰−𝐰∗)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰∗12superscript𝐰subscript𝐰∗𝑇superscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑘𝝃𝐰subscript𝐰∗\displaystyle F_{k}(\mathbf{w})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})+\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast})^{T}\nabla^{2}F_{k}(\boldsymbol{\xi})(\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast})

≥(c)𝑐\displaystyle\overset{(c)}{\geq} μ2​‖𝐰∗−𝐰‖22,𝜇2subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscript𝐰∗𝐰22\displaystyle\frac{\mu}{2}\|\mathbf{w}_{\ast}-\mathbf{w}\|^{2}_{2},

where 𝛏𝛏\boldsymbol{\xi} is a point between 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and 𝐰∗subscript𝐰∗\mathbf{w}_{\ast}, (a) is due to Taylor’s expansion, (b) is because Fk​(𝐰)−Fk​(𝐰∗)≥0subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰∗0F_{k}(\mathbf{w})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})\geq 0, and (c) is because ∇2Fk​(𝛏)⪰μ​𝐈succeeds-or-equalssuperscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑘𝛏𝜇𝐈\nabla^{2}F_{k}(\boldsymbol{\xi})\succeq\mu\mathbf{I}. We also note that A4 does not imply A2, meaning that the quasi-strong convexity does not imply the convexity of Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) [23]. For a complete review of the functional classes satisfying this condition, see [24]. Interestingly, using A4 instead of A2, one can show that the proposed SAFL still has the same convergence rate 𝒪​(1t)𝒪1𝑡\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{t}).

Under A1, A4, and A5, if αt=α0t+1subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝛼0𝑡1\alpha_{t}=\frac{\alpha_{0}}{t+1} for some α0subscript𝛼0\alpha_{0} satisfying α0>1μsubscript𝛼01𝜇\alpha_{0}>\frac{1}{\mu}, the MSE bound of SAFL satisfies

Remark III.7.

In Theorem III.1, we put no constraint on the number of local iterations q𝑞q (a.k.a., the synchronization interval [22]). Therefore, the communication rounds required for T𝑇T iterations is 𝒪​(T​q−1)𝒪𝑇superscript𝑞1\mathcal{O}(Tq^{-1}), which is comparable to the latest results of existing distributed SGD techniques [22].

We are now ready to prove Theorem III.1.

Proof of Theorem III.1: In our proof, we first show that the bound of E​[‖𝐰^t−𝐰∗‖22]𝐸delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript^𝐰𝑡subscript𝐰∗22E[\|\widehat{\mathbf{w}}_{t}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\|_{2}^{2}] is expressed in terms of E​[‖𝐰t(k)−𝐰∗‖22]𝐸delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘subscript𝐰∗22E[\|\mathbf{w}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\|_{2}^{2}] and ‖E​[𝐰t(k)−𝐰∗]‖22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐸delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘subscript𝐰∗22\|E[\mathbf{w}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}]\|_{2}^{2}. IV Extended SAFL for The Overfitting Problem

In many practical scenarios, the FL performance can be degraded due to various reasons such as biased user data, training failures, model poisoning attack, and adversarial attacks [7, 8, 9, 10, 20, 25]. For example, when a user device trains its local model using non-representative data (i.e., certain elements in the dataset are more heavily weighted and represented than others), then the local update of the device might cause a model overfitting problem, resulting in the degradation of the entire FL network performance. To illustrate this behavior, we consider a FL network performing the MNIST classification (see Section V for the detailed setting of the FL network). Depending on the number of digit labels in the local datasets, devices can be classified into two groups: 1) a group with local dataset containing multiple digits (say, 1, 2, 5, 7, and 9) and 2) a group with dataset containing only one digit (say, 2). Due to the data bias, devices in the second group can only learn features of one digit and, as a result, locally trained models might fail to predict other digits (1, 5, 7, and 9). In fact, when the locally trained models of the second group are overfitted to the biased dataset, there would be a performance degradation in the global evaluation model. In our example, if the server uses the local updates of the second group in the update of the global model, then the accuracy of the global model is degraded significantly (see Fig. 4).

In the above example, since the data distributions of devices are known as a priori, we can prevent the performance degradation of the global model by excluding local updates of the second group in the update of the global model. In general, however, it is very difficult for the server to exclude those biased local updates since the local datasets are not revealed to the server due to the privacy of the user data. Instead of making the server to exclude biased local updates, we modify SAFL such that each device can decide whether to upload its local update to the server or not. This decision is done by measuring the performance gap between global and local models. Let h​(𝐳¯t−1)ℎsubscript¯𝐳𝑡1h(\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t-1}) and h​(𝐳t(k))ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑘𝑡h(\mathbf{z}^{(k)}_{t}) be the accuracies of the global evaluation model and the local model in the k𝑘k-th device, respectively, then the performance gap Δt(k)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡𝑘\Delta_{t}^{(k)} between the global and local models is defined as

Δt(k)=|h​(𝐳¯t−1)−h​(𝐳t(k))|h​(𝐳¯t−1)+h​(𝐳t(k))+ϵ,superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡𝑘ℎsubscript¯𝐳𝑡1ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑘𝑡ℎsubscript¯𝐳𝑡1ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑘𝑡italic-ϵ\Delta_{t}^{(k)}=\frac{|h(\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t-1})-h(\mathbf{z}^{(k)}_{t})|}{h(\overline{\mathbf{z}}_{t-1})+h(\mathbf{z}^{(k)}_{t})+\epsilon}, (24)

where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is a small constant to avoid division by zero (e.g., ϵ=10−6italic-ϵsuperscript106\epsilon=10^{-6}). If Δt(k)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡𝑘\Delta_{t}^{(k)} is large, then we consider the local update as a biased update and do not upload the local update to the server. To do so, we set the probability qt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑘q_{t}^{(k)} that the local update 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)} is uploaded to the server as555The choice of the exponential decay is based on our empirical experiences.

qt(k)=exp⁡(−Δt(k)ν),superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡𝑘𝜈q_{t}^{(k)}=\exp\left(-\frac{\Delta_{t}^{(k)}}{\nu}\right), (25)

where ν𝜈\nu is a regularization parameter. Since the probability qt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑘q_{t}^{(k)} decays exponentially with the performance gap Δt(k)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡𝑘\Delta_{t}^{(k)}, if Δt(k)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡𝑘\Delta_{t}^{(k)} is large, then it is highly likely that the device does not send its local update 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)} to the server. By excluding the biased local update 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)} in the update of the global model, we can prevent the performance degradation of the global model.

While the communication cost of SAFL is the same as that of FedAvg, the extended SAFL can reduce the number of local updates uploaded to the server. Let X𝑋X be the total local updates of n𝑛n devices after T𝑇T communication rounds and let Xt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑘X_{t}^{(k)} be the random variable indicating whether the k𝑘k-th device sends the local update to the server, i.e., P​(Xt(k)=1)=qt(k)𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑘P(X_{t}^{(k)}=1)=q_{t}^{(k)} and P​(Xt(k)=0)=1−qt(k)𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑘01superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑘P(X_{t}^{(k)}=0)=1-q_{t}^{(k)}. Then, we have X=∑t=1T∑k=1nXt(k)𝑋superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑘X=\sum\limits_{t=1}^{T}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{n}X_{t}^{(k)} and thus

E​[X]𝐸delimited-[]𝑋\displaystyle E[X] =∑t=1T∑k=1nexp⁡(−Δt(k)ν)≤∑t=1T∑k=1n1=n​T,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡𝑘𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛1𝑛𝑇\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{t=1}^{T}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{n}\exp\left(-\frac{\Delta_{t}^{(k)}}{\nu}\right)\leq\sum\limits_{t=1}^{T}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{n}1=nT, (26)

where n​T𝑛𝑇nT is the total local updates of FedAvg.

In Algorithm II, we summarize the extended SAFL algorithm.

V Simulation

In this section, we investigate the empirical performance of the proposed SAFL on various benchmark datasets, which has been popularly used in the FL evaluation. We first summarize the datasets used in our experiments as follows:

  • •

    MNIST [26]: a dataset consisting of 70,0007000070,000 images of handwritten digits between 00 and 999. All the images are divided into two groups: 60,0006000060,000 images for the training set and 10,0001000010,000 images for the test set666The training and the test sets are split by the command tf.keras.datasets.mnist.load_data() in Tensorflow..

  • •

    Fashion-MNIST [27]: a dataset containing 70,000 grayscale images of clothing (e.g., sneakers, shirts, shoes, and bags). These images are classified into 10 categories. The dataset is divided into two sets: the training set of 60,000 images and the test set of 10,000 images.

  • •

    CIFAR10 [28]: a dataset of color images popularly used in image classification. It consists of 60,000 images of 32×32323232\times 32 pixels from 10 categories: airplane, automobile, bird, cat, deer, dog, frog, horse, ship, and truck. The dataset is divided into two: training set of 50,000 images and test set of 10,000 images.

  • •

    Google speech commands dataset [29]: a dataset popularly used in speech recognition tasks. It consists of 65,000 utterances of 30 short words. To pre-process the GSC dataset, we compute the first 13 mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCC) of a speech signal using 80 filterbanks. To be specific, we first perform a 1024-point short-time Fourier transform (STFT) with frames of 64ms and 75% overlap (at 16kHz sampling frequency) and then compute the power spectrum and MFCC.

In our experiments, each training set is partitioned into n𝑛n subsets (𝒟1,𝒟2,⋯,𝒟n)subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2⋯subscript𝒟𝑛(\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2},\cdots,\mathcal{D}_{n}) of user devices, and each of which is the local dataset in each device. We consider the heterogeneous scenarios where 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} consists of just a few number of class labels (not all the labels) whose sizes are all different (mk=|𝒟k|subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘m_{k}=|\mathcal{D}_{k}|). To be specific, we first set mk=max⁡(⌊xk⌋,1)subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘1m_{k}=\max(\lfloor x_{k}\rfloor,1) where xk∼N​(m¯,σ2)similar-tosubscript𝑥𝑘𝑁¯𝑚superscript𝜎2x_{k}\sim N(\overline{m},\sigma^{2}) is a normal random variable with mean m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} and variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} and ⌊xk⌋subscript𝑥𝑘\lfloor x_{k}\rfloor is the integer satisfying ⌊xk⌋≤xk<⌊xk⌋+1subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘1\lfloor x_{k}\rfloor\leq x_{k}<\lfloor x_{k}\rfloor+1. Then we select a number of digits (e.g., at most 7 digits) for each device at random and choose mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k} samples randomly from the training subset containing only the selected digit labels.

For the MNIST classification, we use LeNet-5, a CNN model consisting of two sets of convolutional and pooling layers, followed by two fully-connected layers and the softmax classifier [30]. For the fashion-MNIST, CIFAR10, and GSC classifications, we use the VGGNet, a CNN model using only 3×3333\times 3 convolutional kernels [31]. The parameter settings of the CNN architectures are shown in Table II. As a loss function in the training process, we use the cross-entropy:

H​(𝐲,𝐲^)=−∑i=110(yi​ln⁡y^i+(1−yi)​ln⁡(1−y^i)),𝐻𝐲^𝐲superscriptsubscript𝑖110subscript𝑦𝑖subscript^𝑦𝑖1subscript𝑦𝑖1subscript^𝑦𝑖H(\mathbf{y},\widehat{\mathbf{y}})=-\sum\limits_{i=1}^{10}(y_{i}\ln\widehat{y}_{i}+(1-y_{i})\ln(1-\widehat{y}_{i})), (27)

where 𝐲^=[y^1⋯y^10]T^𝐲superscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝑦1⋯subscript^𝑦10missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression𝑇\widehat{\mathbf{y}}=\left[\begin{array}[]{ccccccccccccccccccc}\widehat{y}_{1}&\cdots&\widehat{y}_{10}\\ \end{array}\right]^{T} is the predicted softmax output and 𝐲=[y1⋯y10]T𝐲superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑦1⋯subscript𝑦10missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression𝑇\mathbf{y}=\left[\begin{array}[]{ccccccccccccccccccc}y_{1}&\cdots&y_{10}\\ \end{array}\right]^{T} is the one-hot vector of the true label. For all experiments, we set the learning rate α𝛼\alpha to a fixed constant (α=0.002𝛼0.002\alpha=0.002) and set the number of local epochs to E=3𝐸3E=3. We initialize the local model of each device with a different random seed.

We first evaluate the test accuracy of SAFL for different network size (n=40,80, and ​120𝑛4080 and 120n=40,80,\text{ and }120). In this experiment, we set the parameters ϵ=0.3italic-ϵ0.3\epsilon=0.3, L=80𝐿80L=80, m¯=600¯𝑚600\overline{m}=600, and σ2=100superscript𝜎2100\sigma^{2}=100. In Fig. 5, we plot the test accuracy of SAFL and the conventional FedAvg as a function of the communication round. The baseline is the centralized machine learning using the whole dataset. From the results, we observe that the accuracy of all the FL algorithms improves after a sufficient communication rounds (e.g., 100 rounds) and the performance of all FL algorithms eventually converges to the accuracy of the centralized learning technique. In particular, the proposed SAFL outperforms the standard FL technique by a large margin. For example, for n=80𝑛80n=80, SAFL achieves the test accuracy of 95% at the 56-th communication round, resulting in an accuracy improvement of more than 50% (see Fig. 5a). We also observe that the proposed SAFL converges faster than the standard FL technique. For example, when n=120𝑛120n=120, SAFL achieves the accuracy of 80% in 35 communication rounds, while the standard FL technique requires more than 70 rounds to achieve the same level of accuracy (see Fig. 5a). Similar results can be observed from the GSC dataset (see Fig. 5b). In Table. III, we show the top-1 and top-5 accuracy of SAFL in the early stage of SA for n=80𝑛80n=80. From these experiments, we observe that SAFL outperforms the conventional approaches, resulting in an 17% improvement of the top-1 accuracy on the FMNIST dataset.

We next examine the impact of the hyperparameters ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and L𝐿L on the performance of SAFL. In this MNIST experiment, we set n=50𝑛50n=50 and run simulations for different values ϵ=0.3,0.5, and ​0.7italic-ϵ0.30.5 and 0.7\epsilon=0.3,0.5,\text{ and }0.7. In Table. IV, we show the test cost and the test accuracy evaluated at the 505050-th communication round. The best performance of SAFL is highlighted with bold digits. For example, when ϵ=0.3italic-ϵ0.3\epsilon=0.3 and L=80𝐿80L=80, SAFL achieves the smallest MSE (i.e., MSE = 0.1860.1860.186) and the best accuracy (i.e., 95.3%).

We test the performance of SAFL for different training batch sizes (B=50𝐵50B=50, 100, 150, and 200). For all the MNIST experiments, we set the parameters n=100𝑛100n=100, ϵ=0.3italic-ϵ0.3\epsilon=0.3, L=80𝐿80L=80, m¯=600¯𝑚600\overline{m}=600, σ2=100superscript𝜎2100\sigma^{2}=100. The MNIST accuracy are tested after T=100𝑇100T=100 communication rounds. From the results, we observe that the small and moderate batch size can be used to enhance the accuracy of the FL networks, especially when the data size is reduced by half. For example, the batch size B=50𝐵50B=50 gives more than 97.99% SAFL accuracy while the batch size B=200𝐵200B=200 results in less than 97.08% accuracy (see Table. V).

We also test the accuracy of SAFL for different fraction of selected devices (R=0.3𝑅0.3R=0.3, 0.5, and 0.7). From the results, we observe that SAFL outperforms FedAvg, resulting in more than 50% improvement of the test accuracy after 50 communication rounds when R=0.7𝑅0.7R=0.7 (see Fig. 6).

Next we evaluate the test accuracy of the extended SAFL as a function of the total local updates uploaded to the server. Here, we set n=100𝑛100n=100 local devices and count the total local updates in different iterations (T=60𝑇60T=60, 70, and 80). We run 100 trials and compute the mean values (see Table VI). From the results, we observe that SAFL has the same communication cost as FedAvg. While the accuracy of the extended SAFL is comparable to the SAFL accuracy, the extended SAFL significantly reduces the number of the local updates uploaded by the devices, resulting in more than 30% reduction of the local updates (see Table VI).

Finally, we compare the performance of SAFL with the state-of-the-art FL techniques including the temporally weighted aggregation asynchronous (ASTW) [33], IDA [34], FedAvg, FedSGD [35], and FedMA [36]. We also test the combined algorithms: ASTW-SAFL and IDA-SAFL which are combined version of SAFL and ASTW/IDA fusion models [37]. From the results, we observe that SAFL outperforms FedSGD and FedAvg by a large margin, resulting in more than 50% improvement of the test accuracy after 50 communication rounds. The performance of SAFL is comparable to that of FedMA. We also observe that the combination of SAFL and state-of-the-art data fusion model can boost up the learning accuracy significantly. For example, IDA-SAFL can achieve more than 80% accuracy after 50 communication rounds, resulting in more than 30% improvement of the test accuracy over the conventional IDA.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed a FL technique that greatly improves the accuracy and convergence speed of FL. Motivated by the observation that the average-based global model is not necessarily better than local models, the proposed SAFL technique allows each device to choose its own model instead of the global model in the early stage of FL. From the convergence analysis, we showed that SAFL sublinearly converges to the optimal solution under suitable conditions. Also, from the numerical experiments based on various benchmark datasets, we demonstrated that SAFL outperforms the conventional FL technique in terms of the convergence speed and the classification accuracy. In this work, we restricted our attention to the single-task learning scenario. Our future work will be directed toward the extension to the multi-tasking scenario [32].
